content.description: Start on the lower end of the boulder and traverse all the way up and right before topping out.
content.protection: pad and friend to move it as you go
content.location: Uphill from the Black Dog boulder

content.description: Slippery slab to practice trusting your feet on. Don't get shook!
content.location: Between Black Dog and Gallows Pole on the Black Dog boulder.

content.description: Start at the bottom left and work your way up straight and slightly right.
content.protection: Have a strong spotter so you don't tumble down the hill.
content.location: if you walk down down Donaldson Run Trail you will find it to the right of the creek before the overpass; about 10ft up off of the trail.

content.description: Sit start, climb the jugs to a mantle.
content.location: On the face below the traverse for Your Time is Gonna Come

content.description: Ascend up slick feet till you get your wings at the top of the rock!
content.location: On the Black Dog boulder, to the right of Black Dog

content.description: Sit start and slap up the right edge to gain the lip and top out.
content.location: On the face of the Four Sticks boulder that faces the trail

content.description: Stand start. Tread carefully up the slab to claim the top, don't forget to look side to side for holds!
content.location: Slab on the Black Dog boulder just left of Gallows Pole

content.description: Not a classic, but it's there! Start as low as you can and throw up to the lip then mantle.
content.location: On the face you traverse on Your Time is Gonna Come

content.description: Start on the ledge with a left heel hook, don't dab on the rock below with your right foot. Go straight up and complete a glorious mantle without using holds to the right of the corner.
content.location: On the lower face of the Your Time is Gonna Come boulder.

content.description: Great little compression line!! Start using the slopey hold at the start of Gallow’s Pole as a left hand side pull and right hand low on the arete. Bump your way up using the holds on the face and the arete. Cleanest line in the area.
content.location: Just right of Gallow’s Pole on the right arete.

content.description: Sit start on an awful rail that can either be used as a crimp or sloper. Go up and left to the next rail, then move right to a jug and be grateful that you're away from the gallow's pole!
content.location: On the side of the Black Dog boulder that is facing away from the trail.

content.description: Stand start on the lowest holds you can and then get a high foot and rock onto it.
content.location: On the Four Sticks boulder, just on the upstream side of the Black Dog boulder. Four Sticks in on the opposite side of the trail.

content.description: Finicky, but rewarding to send. Start on the two good holds near the bottom left of the arete. Climb up and right on the arete until you can throw for the jugs near the top and top out. Holds on both sides of the arete are fair game, not that there are many.
content.location: On the back of the Black Dog boulder (the side facing away from the trail and opposite Black Dog).

content.description: Start low on the right with a flake and some bad feet. Slap and crimp your way up and left till you get to the sharp corner at the top of the boulder. Pinch with all you've got and mantle up!
content.protection: Couple pads, probably a good spotter
content.location: On the Black Dog boulder. Climbs above the steep face that faces the trail.

content.description:
The Led Zeppelin boulders are a small cluster of boulders that sit on the Potomac Heritage Trail just north of Windy Run Park. They are mostly easy climbing on decent rock, but there are a few hard problems on extremely high quality rock as well. 

  Because this area is right on a trail that hikers enjoy, please consider not bringing large groups, brush away your tick marks and chalk, don't listen to loud music and maybe try to be a good steward by picking up a few pieces of trash each time you go (there's always some). Just be considerate of the other folk on the trail and access to the rocks can remain uncontested.
